subject: Adding tests to existing code

messageBody:
Coolspot714 wrote:

> I found tons of information about test-driven development and
> test-first, but hardly anything about writing tests after the
> application has been developed. Any experiences?

This is untrue. Plenty has been written on the subject; however, you
might not be looking in the right places. On the extremeprogramming
Yahoo! group we talk about adding tests to existing code all the time. :)

Michael Feathers is completing a book entitled "Working Effectively with
Legacy Code" which contains hundreds of pages of advice in this
direction. I spent most of yesterday afternoon talking about this with a
client and his programming group. Let me summarize my description:

1. Test-drive all new code, including new features and defect fixes.
2. For each defect fix:
a. Use the debugger to locate the defective line of code.
b. Extract the defective line of code to a separate class.
c. Test-drive a replacement for that class.
d. Change the existing code /delicately/ to invoke the newly
test-driven replacement.

Over time, you replace the old code with new, tested code. It might take
years, but each time you replace untested code with tested code, you get
closer to a 100% tested system.

What you must /not/ do is try to add 100% test coverage to the current
system starting day 1. That just loses money.

Good luck.
